node.title: Check median timestamp validation is done on wrong section

nodes.bodyText: Is it currently checked on both orphans and the main chain, or orphans only?
both
Ok, so not a chronic trainsmash. The issue is to remove the unnecessary check on orphan blocks.
It's not even consensus-changing, iiuc.

Yeah.
It can happen that an orphan block fails validation because it's looking at the wrong data. Thats the only issue here
Adding the consensus breaking label because it could result in two nodes validating the block differently

node.bodyText:
Currently, the validation check_median_timestamp is done on orphan headers, which should only be on full main headers added to the main chain.
On Tari, we use two types of validators, one for orphans, and one for the main chain. Orphan validators only check rudimentary data, like does the block balance equation work out, does the block have one coinbase etc. Main validation checks all validation steps that are dependent on previous chain blocks, like if each input is a valid out, is the PoW valid, etc.
check_median_timestamp is dependent on previous chain headers. In order to ensure the blockchain moves forward in time, there is a median timestamp rule that specifies that the header's timestamp must be greater than the median timestamp of the previous 11 blocks.
This check has no meaning on the orphan blocks, we need to check this as a main check on the validation

The issue was not critical when it occurred. If this happened, the base node will just continue syncing from a new node and continue o its way as if nothing was wrong.

nodes.bodyText:
Rewind will store all the re-orged blocks in the orphan database.
We should just chose the highest VALID tip and make sure the main chain is that one

Initial reaction is to disagree. The chain metadata keeps track of the valid full block height. We already handle having a chain of valid headers but no/partial blocks. If we reset on an invalid header, we'll have to download valid headers all over again. Same for blocks. If a synced header/block is invalid after syncing others, the blocks that led up to them are still valid so why should we throw them away?
I dont think the rewinding puts the removed blocks back in the orphan database, only updates the orphan tip hash after a reorg, which doesnt seem right. Ah I was mistaken, this happens inside rewind_to_height

  
    
      tari/base_layer/core/src/chain_storage/blockchain_database.rs
    
    
         Line 2004
      in
      09eda1b
    
  
  
    

        
          
           if let Some(block) = removed_blocks.first() {

I dont think the rewinding puts the removed blocks back in the orphan database, only updates the orphan tip hash after a reorg, which doesnt seem right.

It happens in rewind, not reorganise

  
    
      tari/base_layer/core/src/chain_storage/blockchain_database.rs
    
    
         Line 1725
      in
      09eda1b
    
  
  
    

        
          
           txn.insert_chained_orphan(block.clone());

Initial reaction is to disagree. The chain metadata keeps track of the valid full block height. We already handle having a chain of valid headers but no/partial blocks. If we reset on an invalid header, we'll have to download valid headers all over again. Same for blocks. If a synced header/block is invalid after syncing others, the blocks that led up to them are still valid so why should we throw them away?

The header sync does this correctly, it only "swaps" if the syncing chain has higher PoW and is Valid. It will even do that for a partial. Which is correct.
But going into a waiting state, can cause issues as now the database has incomplete state while accepting new blocks.
And in LMDB, we have orphan blocks -> ref via hash. But in the Main Chain, we have header -> height.
So what can happen? A header sync attempts a sync of a few blocks, but fails on connection. No the BN goes back to waiting state meaning it can accept blocks again. Now it accepts new blocks, for those same heights again...
And we have a broken state

The same problem can be said for the block sync. We might download 1000 block headers, and all are valid.
But if the first block in that header is invalid, that chain will always be invalid, and we need to revert back to our old chain

When propagated blocks is active again, and receives a block, it should recognise that the block as an orphan, and not base anything on the headers - This does fit with the error we were seeing so definitely could be a bug there.
Agree with block sync that we need to remove invalid headers up to and after a failed block (mmrs are invalid). Maybe we need to restore the old state, but since we only change for a higher PoW I don't think that is critical.
I don't really understand the problem or solution, but happy if you want to leave this issue open and make a PR against it, showing the problem

node.bodyText:
Currently, syncing is handled by the BN state machine. If the node things its behind, the node will try header_sync to download headers.
If it has enough VALID headers, it will commit them as headers on the main chain, and continue do to so for as long it is provided VALID headers.
If this fails, the node goes to waiting state.
It should not, it should either try and sync the VALID blocks from a node, or delete the headers and on.
But most cases this will return Ok
The block sync has the same problem, after failing, we need to check and see if we need to reset back to our previous state.

node.title: Broken `wasm` tests on `tari`

nodes.bodyText:
Looks like the tari_crypto/wasm feature is missing from key manager.
base_layer/key_manager/Cargo.toml
- wasm = ["wasm-bindgen", "js", "tari_common_types", "console_error_panic_hook"]
+ wasm = ["tari_crypto/wasm", "wasm-bindgen", "js", "tari_common_types", "console_error_panic_hook"]

node.bodyText: PR 134 breaks wasm tests on the tari repository. Reverting the commit from that PR appears to solve the problem.

node.title: fix: make the formatter happy

nodes.bodyText: Looks like clippy is very unhappy with variables outside of format strings. Seems unhelpful.

Looks like a change in rust, #138 uses latest nightly so that is probably why there is a sudden change in clippy.
@stringhandler What do you think? Lock rust nightly down to 1.64 in CI or ignore the lint?
Problem with adding the allow rule is that clippy lints will fail without >=1.65.
allow = ["clippy::uninlined_format_args"]
So I think we have to lock down CI to <1.65
Probably worth pinning the nightly version for fmt so you can upgrade it only when you want to

It's a really good lint, actually.
But better to make it a WARNING in lints.toml rather than hold the compiler version back. Then someone can come clean up after us.

But better to make it a WARNING in lints.toml rather than hold the compiler version back. Then someone can come clean up after us.

I agree, might be a problem that you require +nightly to run cargo lints, that is cargo +stable lints clippy won't work until stable is on rust 1.65 (uninlined_format_args isn't recignised by clippy < 1.65), maybe thats ok. Otherwise, we should probably fix these lints.

I agree, might be a problem that you require +nightly to run cargo lints, that is cargo +stable lints clippy won't work until stable is on rust 1.65 (uninlined_format_args isn't recignised by clippy < 1.65), maybe thats ok. Otherwise, we should probably fix these lints.

Yes, just ran into this on #143, but I think we can live with this until these features are stabilised
#143 covers this plus a few other bits and bobs, incl updating the code coverage script, so going to close this.
